instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 55v on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Dear users,

I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A. No liquid damage or any other visible damage, only screen replaced 1 year ago. Worked until today.

When you open the laptop for 2 inch, it shows backlight. But as soon as you open the screen completely the whole backlight fates out and stop working.

When i measure at <CAPACITOR>C8473</CAPACITOR> the voltage goes up to 55v with the backlight not working and the laptop all open. When I close the laptop again and open only for 2 inches, it starts working again and at <CAPACITOR>C8473</CAPACITOR> the voltage is back at 44v. 

Could it be a LCD problem or is there anything else going on?

Regards,
<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 55v on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://support.apple.com/13-inch-macbook-pro-display-backlight-service[/URL]
Being a 2017 machine it's gotta be harder to get it serviced but worth trying.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A 55v on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
55V means the LED strip is open at that time.
This is classic flexgate problem.
If you cannot get the screen replaced by Apple, may not worth to buy new LCD assembly...
